Michael Nelson , a professor of political science at rhodes college in memphis, is blunt about how the race would evolve with Bill Frist in it. it's a wide-open race, unless Bill Frist decides to run. and then the race is over, if he does. it's that simple. he can clear the field in terms of any other candidate having any realistic chance at all of being elected, he said. david kanervo, chairman of the political science department at austin peay state university, said the biggest factor other than Bill Frist is the economy. a prolonged downturn, he said, would probably force candidates

Marcus Stuttard , deputy head of aim at the lse, explains the plans to create aim italia. we are having a mock consultation on rules there and are talking to banks on getting nomad status. we have always had pan-european ambitions, he said. he notes that the italian market is very different to the uk, with a lot of businesses being family owned.
